From my (probably limited) understanding of neurobiology, such a
conservati=
on of energy principle would not be applicable to the model
of neurons firi=
ng. At least not in the sense that I believe you are
describing.

'Energy' =
as it were, is not really 'transferred' between any given
neurons in such a=
 system. Neurons only interact via neurotransmitters
being released into an=
d absorbed from the synaptic cleft between said
neurons. Electrical energy =
(which I gather is to what you are
referring) is confined to within a parti=
cular neuron itself. In a
properly functioning neuron, this energy is neith=
er received nor
transmitted. In fact, (and I may be mistaken here, so someb=
ody correct
me if I am) I beleive that the effects of such neurological dis=
eases
as multiple sclerosis are actually precipitated by this electrical
en=
ergy escaping the cell due to a degeneration of the myelin sheath
that woul=
d normally cover the axon of the cell, along which the
electrical signals w=
ithin the cell travel from dendrite to axon
terminal.

If it were the case =
that a conservation of energy principle was
applied to such a model, and th=
e electrical signals *were* being
transmitted cell-to-cell, this would impo=
se a ceiling on the number of
layers possible in the network, degree of rec=
ursion in feedback
networks, etc. due to what would be inevitable signal de=
gradation to
the point of no longer being usable. That is unless there was =
also the
provision for 'repeater' cells/nodes in the network (a concept tha=
t I
have personally not encountered as of yet).

Basically, the energy that=
 is 'distributed' across connecting neurons
actually comes from within the =
cell (insert complex/detailed
discussion about mitochondria, phosphorylatio=
n, etc. here... haha),
itself being a function of the type, amount, and pos=
sibly other
yet-to-be-discovered properties of the neurotransmitters (and p=
ossibly
other chemicals as well) that are within the synaptic cleft at the
=
time that the firing was initiated.

A better analogy (I believe) would be =
the one proposed by a large body
of the literature: a single neuron is a bl=
ack-box function. It takes a
given input (absorbing neurotransmitters from =
the synaptic cleft) and
produces an output (releasing neurotransmitters int=
o the synaptic
cleft). Any conservation of energy principle is resetricted =
to being
applied to the processes occurring within the cell itself, because=
 in
this (limited) sense the cell is acting as a closed system for that
ele=
ctrical energy.

Hope this helps,

Eric

PS Anyone, feel free to correct me=
 if any of this is off-base or just
plain wrong too. I'm just going by my c=
ursory understanding of these
things, and so could be mistaken about some o=
f this.
